channel.title: CSS Weekly
channel.description: Weekly e-mail roundup of latest CSS articles, tutorials, tools and experiments

item.title: Issue #179
item.dc:creator: Zoran Jambor
item.description: Learn how to create arbitrarily-shaped UI components using CSS properties and SVG’s capabilities, how to enhance performance using prefetching, preloading & prebrowsing, and more.
item.content:encoded:
CSS vs. SVG: Shapes and Arbitrarily-Shaped UI Components

Sara Soueidan goes over techniques for creating arbitrarily-shaped UI components using CSS properties and SVG’s capabilities, and a mix of both!


The Anatomy of Responsive Images

Jake Archibald gives a nice visual overview of how exactly responsive images work.


From Our Sponsor

Learn to Design 2015 Course Bundle

Learn. Imagine. Design. This amazing bundle contains 8 courses that cover everything from creating prototypes with interactions and transitions, to designing beautiful & user-friendly websites and creating stunning pixel art graphics for video games.


Articles & Tutorials

Prefetching, Preloading, Prebrowsing

Robin Rendle explains how to improve the user experience in a noticeable way by using some performance enhancing techniques.


CSS Grid and The Box Alignment Module

Rachel Andrew takes a quick look at how Flexbox properties work with Grid Layout.


Diving Deep into SVG Animations

Daniel O’Connor shares his story of the trial and error of creating SVG animations.


Gulp for Beginners

An excellent introduction into Gulp (you are using it, aren’t you?) by Zell Liew.


Jobs

UX Designer (HTML/CSS) at Booking.com

Booking,com is looking for the world’s smartest designers. As a member of our Front End team you’ll be given the freedom to make meaningful and measurable improvements impacting millions of people. You’ll join us at our beautiful Amsterdam HQ and work with some of our industry’s smartest people.


Tools

IE Virtual Machines

Test versions of IE from 6 through 11 and Microsoft Edge using virtual machines you download and manage locally.


Sweet Alert

A beautiful, highly customizable replacement for JavaScript’s “Alert” dialog.


Inspiration

CSS UFO

Ross B. played around with orbiting dynamics using transform, transform-origin, and backface-visibility. The result is pretty great.


Until Next Week

item.title: Issue #178
item.dc:creator: Zoran Jambor
item.description: Find out how CSS Grid Layout works, how to style checkboxes and radio buttons with CSS and SVG, how to create and bring to life rounded shapes and circles using CSS animations, and more.
item.content:encoded:
The Future of Layout with CSS: Grid Layouts

Patrick Brosset looks at the wonderful world of the CSS Grid Layout, a relatively new W3C specification that has partially started to see the day in some browsers.


CSS vs SVG: Styling Checkboxes and Radio Buttons

Sara Soueidan tackles custom HTML form styling—specifically checkbox and radio inputs.


From Our Sponsor

Set Yourself Apart

Master your craft at the conference for people who make websites. An Event Apart is the web design and development conference where groundbreaking techniques break first. It’s where mission-critical techniques are mastered, and new ideas become industry-wide best practices.

Register now and save $100 with discount code AEACSSW.


Articles & Tutorials

Spheres

Donovan Hutchinson demonstrates how to create and bring to life rounded shapes and circles using CSS animations.


DevTools Tips For Sublime Text Users

Addy Osmani on how to take advantage of your existing knowledge of features in Sublime Text and apply them to another powerful tool in your arsenal — the Chrome DevTools.


What IS Flexbox?

Scott Vandehey gives a nice introduction into Flexbox, a layout mode added to CSS to replace hacky float and table layouts.


Tight Fitting SVG Shapes, the Present and Future

In this article, Ana Tudor tackles an interesting problem: what happens when the stroke of an element grows in such a way that it appears cut off?


Tools

Type­set.js

Typeset is an HTML pre-proces­sor for web ty­pog­ra­phy. It uses no client-side JavaScript but gives you hang­ing punc­tu­a­tion, soft hy­phen in­ser­tion, op­ti­cal mar­gin out­dents, small-caps con­ver­sion and punctuation substitution.


jQuerymy.js

jQuery.my is a plugin for real-time two-way data binding. It mutates object given as data source, reflecting interactions between user and UI.


Inspiration

Building to Learn

Susan Robertson explains why is building something that interests you one of the best ways to learn something new, both on the web and elsewhere in life.


Until Next Week

Happy coding,
Zoran Jambor

item.title: Issue #177
item.dc:creator: Zoran Jambor
item.description: Find out why you should refactor your CSS, what CSS Modules is, how to create charts with CSS, and more.
item.content:encoded:
Why You Need to Refactor Your CSS

Nathan Rambeck on why you should regularly refactor your CSS.


CSS Modules

Glen Maddern explains what CSS Modules is, and why it’s the future.


From Our Sponsor

Xcode for Designers: Create iOS Apps in 5 Days

Through 25 video lessons, you will learn how to master Xcode and start creating native iOS apps. You’ll learn the ins and outs of Xcode 6’s interface, as well as everything from variables to strings to functions.


Articles & Tutorials

From Russia With Love: Behind The Responsive Redesign Of Kremlin.ru

Insights behind the responsive redesign of Kremlin.ru, the challenges and constraints, creative front-end solutions, unusual budgets and stakeholders.


The @font-face Dilemma

Chris Manning goes over @font-face and how it can be problematic, different ways to improve font loading performance and the prospects for better font loading in the near future.


Making Charts with CSS

Robin Rendle looks at plain CSS methods for styling data.


The State of Responsive Images in 2015

Paddi MacDonnell looks at the current state of responsive images, explains what works, where the problems and pitfalls still lie, and how you can use responsive images today.


Getting Responsive Tables to Behave

Joshua Hibbert shares another useful solution for responsive tables.


How-To: 8-Bit Hovers

Tiffany Stoik explains how to create interesting 8-bit inspired, playful hover effects.


Tools

LazyLoad

LazyLoad is a fast, lightweight and flexible script for loading images only when they’re about to enter the viewport of a scrollable area.


Simple Notifications

A very lightweight, customizable notifications utility with zero external dependencies.


Inspiration

Pure CSS Bars

Rafael González created beautiful CSS Bars you can actually use in your projects.

item.title: Issue #176
item.dc:creator: Zoran Jambor
item.description: Learn how to recreate a basic interface with Flexbox, how to build a circular menu using CSS Clip Paths, how to speed up the rendering of your website using critical CSS, and more.
item.content:encoded:
Laying Out A Flexible Future For Web Design With Flexbox

Ben Gremillion shows how to create a basic user interface using flexbox.


Building A Circular Navigation with CSS Clip Paths

Sara Soueidan explains how to build a circular menu using CSS Clip Paths.


From Our Sponsor

Learn How to Animate like a pro with Greensock

If you’re a developer who eagerly wants to learn how to master the fascinating animation platform, GreenSock – and thereby become the web animation superstar you secretly fantasize about being – then this is the workshop for you!


Articles & Tutorials

Understanding Critical CSS

You can speed up the rendering of your website using critical CSS. Dean Hume shows how to use Grunt/Gulp tasks to identify critical CSS and inline it in the head of your pages.


Understanding CSS: Selector Specificity

Daniel Eden explains how CSS specificity works and shares some advice on keeping your CSS specificity low.


Strategies for Cache-Busting CSS

Chris Coyier goes over different ways of cache-busting CSS.


Deconfusing Pre- and Post-processing

“Pre-processors” and “post-processors” don’t exist. They are CSS processors, taking care of both authoring and optimisation features.


The Hamburger Menu Doesn't Work

James Archer explains in detail why hamburger menus don’t work and demonstrates a couple of better alternatives.


Jobs

Senior Web Developer at OneTaste

OneTaste’s mission is to bring Orgasm to One Billion people! We are looking for a Web developer to help create and manage a world class website for our organization. Strong knowledge of CSS3 & HTML5. See our Jobs Page for full job description onetaste.us/jobs/ and apply online.


Tools

Paradeiser

Paradeiser is small and sleek mobile navigation script (a good alternative to the hamburger menu).


CSS Nano

CSS Nano is a modular CSS minifier, composed of single-responsibility PostCSS plugins.


Inspiration

Animated SVG Hero Slider

Claudia Romano created an amazing full page slider, with animated SVG elements used as transition effects.


Until Next Week

item.title: Issue #175
item.dc:creator: Zoran Jambor
item.description: Learn how to debug CSS Keyframe Animations, how to add further meaning and information to the BEM naming convention, how can CSS Modules help you emulate local scope and control dependencies in front-end components, and more.
item.content:encoded:
Debugging CSS Keyframe Animations

Sarah Drasner explains in detail how to effectively debug CSS Keyframe Animations.


BEMIT: Taking the BEM Naming Convention a Step Further

Harry Roberts explains how to add further meaning and information to the BEM naming convention.


From Our Sponsor

User Engagement Design Course

This engaging course will teach you about people, how they think, decide, remember and what motivates them to take action and increase your conversion.


Articles & Tutorials

Making and Breaking the Web With CSS Gradients

Are you checking your stylesheets for outdated (gradient) syntax and making sure you have an unprefixed modern equivalent on a regular basis? Well, you should.


Advanced CSS Filters

Vincent De Oliveira introduces backdrop-filter CSS property, which applies filters to the backdrop of an element, not to its background.


CSS Modules: Why This Is the Most Significant Improvement to CSS in Years

Josh Johnston explains how can css-modules help you emulate local scope and control dependencies in front-end components.


Use Gulp to Automate Your Critical Path CSS

Chris Ruppel shows how to use Gulp to automate the process of generating your critical path CSS.


Preload Hints For Web Fonts

Bram Stein explains how will pre­load hints im­prove web font per­for­mance (when browsers start supporting them).


Jobs

Senior Web Developer at OneTaste

OneTaste’s mission is to bring Orgasm to One Billion people! We are looking for a Web developer to help create and manage a world class website for our organization. Strong knowledge of CSS3 & HTML5. See our Jobs Page for full job description onetaste.us/jobs/ and apply online.


Tools

CSSfmt

CSSfmt is a tool that automatically formats CSS source code.


Stretchy

Stretchy is a small, standalone library that handles form element autosizing.


Inspiration

CSS Cubes and Pyramids

Ana Tudor created another impressive CSS animation that you absolutely must see.

item.title: Issue #174
item.dc:creator: Zoran Jambor
item.description: Learn how to design pie charts with CSS, how to create graphical text effects using CSS and SVG, how to eliminate the unused CSS from your frameworks, and more.
item.content:encoded:
Designing Flexible, Maintainable Pie Charts With CSS and SVG

Lea Verou shows how to design flexible and maintainable pie charts with CSS.


CSS vs. SVG: Graphical Text Effects

Sara Soueidan goes over a few techniques for creating graphical text effects using CSS and SVG.


From Our Sponsor

An Event Apart

Master your craft with three days of design, code, and content. An Event Apart is the web design and development conference where groundbreaking techniques break first. Watch 25+ hours of free talks online, and register now to save $100 with discount code AEACSSW.


Articles & Tutorials

Modern CSS Layout, Power and Responsibility

Rachel Andrew shares some thoughts on modern CSS layouts. (New layout tools may actually cause as many problems as they solve.)


Constructing CSS Quantity Queries On The Fly

You want to build a dynamic CSS module and style items based on the count of siblings? CSS quantity queries solve just that—now with a tool to generate CSS.


Use Gulp and UnCSS to slim down your CSS framework

Chris Ruppel on how to eliminate the unused CSS from your frameworks.


Is PostCSS a Game Changer?

PostCSS is gaining some serious traction. As such, it has an ever-growing, pleasantly plump plethora of plugins. If you’re not familiar with it, you should read this.


Trello CSS Guide

Trello’s CSS guide provides some architecture for writing clean and maintainable CSS.


Tools

CSS conic-gradient() Polyfill

A polyfill that lets you experiment with CSS conic-gradients now.


Dragula

Dragula is a simple drag and drop library that has no dependencies and an excellent browser support (IE7+).


Inspiration

The 'I' in Team

Shawna Moser shares a few of the simple ideas that can help you become a valuable member of any team you join.

item.title: Issue #173
item.dc:creator: Zoran Jambor
item.description: Find out why you should add PostCSS to your workflow, how to to create sticky elements with pure CSS, how exactly em and rem units work, and more.
item.content:encoded:
PostCSS – Sass Killer or Preprocessing Pretender?

Ashley Nolan gives a comprehensive overview of PostCSS and outlines why it could be a useful tool for you to add to your workflow.


The Trouble With Preprocessing Based on Future Specs

Chris Coyier shares a couple of things you should consider if you want to use CSS postprocessors (PostCSS).


From Our Sponsor

Learn the latest email marketing trends to help grow your business

We’ll show you some of the best examples from leading brands who are using email to drive business growth. Learn how they’re using the latest trends including responsive email design, triggered and transactional emails plus much more.


Articles & Tutorials

Comprehensive Guide: When to Use Em vs. Rem

Kezz Bracey explains exactly how em and rem units work, and demonstrates how to best leverage them in your designs.


Position Sticky: Scroll-to-top-then-fixed in Pure CSS

Dudley Storey shows how to create ’sticky’ elements with pure CSS. (Unfortunately, browser support isn’t great at the moment.)


Some Things I’ve Learned about CSS so Far

Cole Peters shares some CSS-related tips that you might found both valuable and practical.


Creating Better CSS

Good CSS requires a good foundation, some well thought-out coding principles and a selection of tools to keep you on the right track.


Thinking Ahead: CSS Scroll Snap Points

Guil Hernandez gives a nice introduction into scroll snap points, a feature that gives users a fluid and precise scrolling experience for touch and input devices.


Inspiration

The Web We Have to Save

The rich, diverse, and free web that we love might be dying. (An excellent essay on the past and future of the web by Hossein Derakhshan.)


Until Next Week

item.title: Issue #172
item.dc:creator: Zoran Jambor
item.description: Find out what PostCSS is, how to use quantity ordering with pure CSS, how to style the contents of the SVG <use> element, and more.
item.content:encoded:
It's Time for Everyone to Learn About PostCSS

If you’re writing CSS, you should learn what PostCSS is, what it really does, and what it can be used for.


Quantity Ordering With CSS

The flexbox specification contains properties that enable us to modify markup in new ways. Drew Minns explains how to use quantity ordering with pure CSS.


From Our Sponsor

Smashing Web & Graphics eBook Bundle: 7 eBooks for only $18!

This bundle of 7 popular eBooks covers some serious design ground including the fundamentals of HTML5, CSS3 and JavaScript, as well as mastering such huge Adobe programs as Photoshop, Illustrator, and Fireworks.


Articles & Tutorials

Styling SVG <use> Content with CSS

An in-depth article Sara Soueidan on how to style the contents of the SVG <use> element and overcome some challenges it brings.


Print Stylesheet Approaches: Blacklist vs Whitelist

Chris Coyier discusses the advantages and disadvantages of different approaches to print stylesheets.


Perfecting a CSS 3D Animation

Miguel Palhas shares a couple of good CSS animation tips & tricks while explaining how his 3D animated atom experiment works.


I Left My System Fonts in San Francisco

Craig Hockenberry on using system font in the new version of OS X (new -apple-system font family).


Performance: Showing Versus Telling

The most challenging part of performance optimization, writes Lara Hogan, is getting other people to care about it.


Tools

Stylelint

Modern CSS linter. Supports the latest CSS syntax and features, including custom properties, range media features and calc().


SpinKit

A really nice collection of loading indicators animated with CSS.


Inspiration

Scrolling Prefixes

A very interesting text effect created with a little bit of CSS and JavaScript by Maik Macho.

item.title: Issue #171
item.dc:creator: Zoran Jambor
item.description: Learn how to provide accessible fallback for SVG graphics, what Atomic OOBEMITSCSS is, how to create more credible animations by applying a little bit of physics to web design, and more.
item.content:encoded:
Art-Directing an SVG Embedded Using object

A case study of embedding, art-directing and providing accessible fallback for SVG graphics by Sara Soueidan.


Atomic OOBEMITSCSS

Una Kravets shares various CSS methodologies used in creating Atomic OOBEMITSCSS.


From Our Sponsor

UI/UX Designer Bundle

Through 5 video courses, you will learn how to master UX. You’ll learn everything you need to know to delight your users and to increase conversion rates of your designs.


Articles & Tutorials

Newton Meets CSS

Evangelina Ferreira explains how to create smoother and more credible animations by simply applying a little bit of physics to web design.


Exploring CSS Layout Techniques

Chris Coyier explores different techniques for solving a very interesting design problem.


Animation In Your Style Guide

Val Head on why animation absolutely belongs in your style guides.


CSS Triangles: How do they work?

Jess Jones explains how CSS triangles work, and why should you use them in the first place.


The Web’s Cruft Problem

TJ VanToll argues that the need to monetize content is causing an overload of cruft that is hurting the web and giving rise to tools like Facebook Instant. Quite an interesting read.


Tools

Material Design Lite

An implementation of Google’s Material Design components in vanilla CSS, JS, and HTML.


PurifyCSS

A tool that detects which CSS classes your app is using and creates a file without the unused CSS.


Inspiration

Pure CSS 3d Perspective Render

A beautiful 3d text effect created with pure CSS by Rafael González.

item.title: Issue #170
item.dc:creator: Zoran Jambor
item.description: Find out what is the current status of element queries, what are the most common ways to make shapes using CSS, how to fix scrolling performance with will-change property, and more.
item.content:encoded:
Container Queries: Once More Unto the Breach

Tying responsive CSS to viewport sizes can lead to tangled stylesheets—Mat Marquis issues a challenge to find a simpler solution.


Working with Shapes in Web Design

Robin Rendle outlines some of the most common ways to make circles, triangles, and polygons using CSS, and jots down the advantages and disadvantages for these methods.


From Our Sponsor

An Event Apart

Master your craft with three days of design, code, and content. An Event Apart is the web design and development conference where groundbreaking techniques break first. Watch 25+ hours of free talks online, and register now to save $100 with discount code AEACSSW.


Articles & Tutorials

Fix Scrolling Performance with CSS will-change Property

Chris Ruppel explains how to improve performance of pages that use background-attachment: fixed;.


Native CSS Scroll Snap Points

Sergey Gospodarets gives an overview of the scroll-snap CSS property, which is already implemented in many next versions of browsers.


What a CSS Code Review Might Look Like

Geoff Graham on how can code reviews help you release code into the wild with confidence.


A Guide to the Front-End Interview Process

A brief guide for anyone preparing to interview for roles related to front-end development.


Complex Responsive Animations

Trying to perfect UI animations against the moving target of a responsive layout? Sarah Drasner has got some tips on how to balance these complementary concerns.


Jobs

Front End Developer at Pusher

Do you want to design something that makes developers’ lives better? Pusher is all about helping developers, and our website and dashboard is key to our success. We’re looking for a designer-developer who believes that design can make a meaningful difference and cares about how it is implemented.


Tools

Tota11y

Tota11y is an accessibility visualization toolkit that helps visualize how your site performs with assistive technologies.


Remodal

Responsive, lightweight, fast, synchronized with CSS animations, fully customizable modal window plugin with declarative configuration and hash tracking.


Inspiration

SVG Flying Saucer

Chris Gannon created an ultimate SVG proof that UFOs exist, and that they actually really love cows.

item.title: Issue #169
item.dc:creator: Zoran Jambor
item.description: Find out how your CSS impacts page performance, how to make a realistic text effect with a tilt-shift blur using CSS, what the future of CSS might look like, and more.
item.content:encoded:
Performance Beyond the Page Load

In this talk Ryan Seddon explains in detail how your CSS impacts page performance and how to diagnose performance issues.


Creating Realistic Text with CSS

Lucas Bebber shows how to make a realistic text effect with a tilt-shift blur, using CSS and JavaScript.


From Our Sponsor (via Syndicate)

See how your Visitors are really using your Website...

Hotjar is a new and affordable way to improve your site UX and conversion rate by using Heatmaps, Visitor Recordings, Funnel and Form Analysis, Polls and Surveys… all in one central interface.


Articles & Tutorials

Interoperable CSS: A CSS Standard for the Loader Age

Glen Maddern gives an interesting look at what the future of CSS might look like.


Discover the Power of SVG

Sara Soueidan explores how scalable vector graphics can be used for much more than just creating and animating shapes.


Pseudo-Classes, Pseudo-Elements, and Colon Notation

Ire Aderinokun explores the difference between pseudo-elements and pseudo-classes and which colon syntax should be used.


Mathematical Web Typography

Brent Jackson shares an approach for creating modular typographic systems on the Web.


Accessible Footnotes with CSS

Hugo Giraudel considers how in-document linked footnotes can be created to be maintainable and accessible with just HTML and CSS.


Tools

Type.js

Type.js allows you to take finer typographic control of type styles on the web.


Detecting CSS Animation and Transition End with JavaScript

A simple script that will help you detect the end of CSS animations and transitions.


Inspiration

Animated Sign Up Flow

Sebastiano Guerriero created a concept of a pricing table that animates into a sign up form once the user selects a plan.

item.dc:creator: Zoran Jambor
item.description: Learn how to use SVGs on your websites, how to write good, readable, and maintainable CSS, and more.
item.content:encoded:
SVG on the Web — A Practical Guide

Jake Giltsoff gives a practical overview of how you can use SVGs on your websites — with some tips and tricks along the way to get the most out of them.


Writing Good CSS

Mark Rabey shares his thoughts on writing readable, maintainable, and scalable CSS.


From Our Sponsor

Kickstart your Portfolio at SlideRule's UX Design School

In this 8-week Online Workshop, you’ll learn user research, visual design, personas, and wireframing, by working on real projects under the mentorship of expert designers from Stanford d.School, Adobe, Thoughtworks and Pivotal Labs! Registrations end soon! Spots are limited.


Articles & Tutorials

Checkbox Trickery with CSS

Will Boyd showcases some of the creative things you can do with checkboxes in pure CSS (without JavaScript).


Useful Flexbox Technique: Alignment Shifting Wrapping

Chris Coyier shows how can flexbox help you solve a seemingly impossible design problem.


A Look at Some CSS Methodologies

Kieran Potts gives an overview of different CSS methodologies.


Responsive Web Design Email Course

Patrick Wong explains the basics of responsive web design in this 6-day email course.


Responsive Typography With Sass Maps

Managing responsive typographic rhythm isn’t easy. Jonathan Suh shows how Sass maps make responsive typography much more manageable.

CSS conic-gradient() Polyfill

Polyfill for conic-gradient() and repeating-conic-gradient() by Lea Verou.


Angular Interactive Box-Model Diagram

An app to visualize the box-model and see how changing the value of box-sizing affects element size.

Pop Fractal Art

Gregor Adams created a beautiful piece of art in pure CSS.

item.title: Issue #167
item.dc:creator: Zoran Jambor
item.description: Learn how to effectively build HTML Email Templates, what are the benefits of CSS naming conventions and methodologies, how to use most of the new features from CSS selectors level 4, and more.
item.content:encoded:
Things I've Learned About Building & Coding HTML Email Templates

Lee Munroe shares everything he learned about building and coding HTML newsletters.


CSS Layers

Cathy Dutton looks at some popular CSS naming conventions and methodologies and outlines the benefits they can bring to your projects.


From Our Sponsor (via Syndicate)

Learn UI/UX design skills with an expert mentor

Do you ever wish your websites looked more “professional”?

Take one of our online UI/UX design courses with hands-on projects & 1-on-1 mentorship from expert designers at companies like Twitter & Dropbox — we guarantee you’ll see an improvement in your work.


Articles & Tutorials

The Future Generation of CSS Selectors: Level 4

Louis Lazaris discusses and demonstrates how to use most of the new features from CSS selectors level 4.


Importing CSS Breakpoints Into JavaScript

Mike Herchel demonstrates a simple way to keep your media queries in CSS and JavaScript in sync.


Pushing the Limits of :visited with CSS Blend Modes

Stelian Firez shows how to effectively style visited links using blend modes.


How Can I Make My Forms A Little More Accessible?

Rob Copeland shows how to easily improve the accessibility of your site.


5 Lesser Used CSS Selectors

Ire Aderinokun explores lesser known CSS selectors and gives some use cases for them.


Tools

Gradify

Gradify is a tool that produces scalable and responsive CSS gradients as placeholders for images.


Quttons

Quttons are buttons made of Quantum Paper (a digital paper that can change its size, shape and color to accommodate new content).


Inspiration

Animated Weather Icons

Josh Bader created a nice set of beautiful, animated, pure-css weather icons. Simple, but very effective.
